title: Jesuit reduction
summary: The Jesuit reductions were a type of settlement for indigenous people specifically in the Rio Grande do Sul area of Brazil, Paraguay and neighbouring Argentina in South America, established by the Jesuit Order early in the 17th century and wound up in the 18th century with the banning of the Jesuit order in several European countries.[1] Subsequently, it has been called an experiment in "socialist theocracy" or a rare example of "benign colonialism".
